Award.AwardTitle: EAGER Germination: Cultivating Creativity and Innovation in Engineering Research through Mindfulness Training
Award.AbstractNarration:
The University of Wisconsin (UW)-Madison, under the direction of Prof. Susan C. Hagness is proposing a project to develop and evaluate a radically new learning framework for engineering graduate students that is intended to cultivate a highly creative, innovative, and grand-challenge-focused research culture. The framework is based on mindfulness training: understanding the brain, emotional styles, and how they can be modified through meditation and other contemplative practices. The rationale for introducing engineering graduate students to contemplative practices stems from recent studies suggesting that mindfulness meditation improves insight problem solving, reduces cognitive rigidity, and positively impacts creativity outcomes, as well as increasing empathy and compassion. The underlying hypothesis is that cultivating creativity, innovation, intellectual risk-taking, altruism, and overall well-being "through mindfulness training" will collectively enhance graduate students' skills to conceive and conduct transformative research, and will motivate them to address societal challenges through the research problems they pursue.

Contemplative neuroscience research studies have demonstrated that brain plasticity can be exploited via mindfulness training to produce measurable effects on brain function, and physical and emotional well-being. The project represents an entirely new exploration of the potential role of mindfulness in cultivating attributes in the brain that are essential to conceiving and conducting transformative research with societal impact. The project will yield a scalable and adaptable curriculum for training engineering graduate students, integrated assessment tools suitable for evaluating creative capacity, emotional styles, and well-being, and documentation of the effectiveness of the proposed learning framework in enhancing graduate student ability and interest to conduct societally-focused transformative research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This pilot study, conducted at the University of Wisconsin-Madison, explored a radically new learning framework for engineering graduate students that is intended to cultivate a highly creative, innovative, and grand-challenge-focused research culture. The framework is based on mindfulness training: understanding the brain, emotional styles, and how they can be modified through meditation and other contemplative practices. The rationale for introducing engineering graduate students to contemplative practices stems from recent studies suggesting that mindfulness meditation improves insight problem solving, reduces cognitive rigidity, and positively impacts creativity outcomes, as well as increasing empathy and compassion. The underlying hypothesis is that cultivating creativity, innovation, intellectual risk-taking, altruism, and overall well-being through mindfulness training will collectively enhance graduate students' skills to conceive and conduct transformative research, and will motivate them to address societal challenges through the research problems they pursue.

Contemplative neuroscience research studies have demonstrated that brain plasticity can be exploited via mindfulness training to produce measurable effects on brain function, and physical and emotional well-being. The learning framework comprised eight 50-minute weekly sessions of mindfulness training taught by two experienced facilitators. Roughly half the participants were part of an experimental cohort and the remainder were part of a wait-list control cohort. All participants completed an online questionnaire before and after the intervention for the experimental group. The pre- and post-test questionnaires made use of a variety of standard and custom well-being and creativity measures. The variables that were assessed within the pre- and post-test questionnaires included emotional and physical well-being, research satisfaction, desire to contribute to the betterment of society, and creativity. Participants in both groups completed a summative assessment questionnaire at the end of the study that focused on the students' own perceptions of the impact of the intervention on their research and overall well-being.

Intellectual merit:  Our analysis of the pre- and post-test data included independent t-tests to compare the experimental and control groups at baseline for each outcome variable, but primarily focused on statistically significant changes in participants from the first to the second questionnaire that differed as a function of group. The findings are extremely encouraging. For example, over the 48-item Emotional Styles scale measuring emotional health, the experimental group showed a significant increase between the pre- and post-test compared to the control group. In particular, for the Resilience subscale, which captures how fast one bounces back from negative emotions, and the Outlook subscale, which captures optimism and one’s ability to sustain positive emotions, the experimental group had a significant increase, whereas the control group did not. The 15-item scale measuring Creativity Characteristics also showed a significant interaction effect, with the experimental group exhibiting increased endorsement of creativity characteristics. No such effect was observed in the control group. We also observed encouraging trends in the expected direction on the Self-Awareness subscale of the Emotional Styles scale, and the custom 7-item Satisfaction with Research Questionnaire. Notably, there was a correlation between scores on the Creativity Characteristics Scale and performance on the Alternative Uses Task, a behavioral measure of creativity wherein participants are asked to think of as many alternate uses of a common object  as possible within a fixed period of time.

Broader impact: The summative assessment posed several open ended questions, including "In what ways has the training impacted your research and other professional work?" Although not all participants indicated that they had noticed changes, numerous participants provided exceptionally compelling responses indicating how the mindfulness practices were helping them better manage their emotions, ease anxiety, be more focused and efficient in their work, better handle overwhelming situations, and deal with research setbacks in a positive manner.

The project represents an entirely new exploration of the potential role of mindfulness in cultivating attributes in the brain that are essential to conceiving and conducting transformative research with societal impact. The 70 engineering graduate students who participated in this pilot study work on research problems that have the potential to address important societal needs and they will go on to research careers where they will be the next generation of innovators in their field. Although we were not able to do long term tracking during the one-year pilot study, we anticipate that some of the study participants have continued with their mindfulness practice. We have heard in detail about one such occurrence where the participant not only continued their practice, but also shared the skills learned with other engineering professionals.

The results of this pilot study serve as preliminary evidence of the efficacy of eight weeks of mindfulness training – a curriculum that is anticipated to be scalable and adaptable – in enhancing the ability and interest of engineering graduate students to conduct innovative societally impactful and transformative research through increased creative capacity and improved overall health and emotional well-being.
